Question: With a _______ Tabular Editor 3 license, you can connect to a remote dataset in a Power BI Premium Capacity Workspace.
PossibleAnswers: Business
Desktop
Enterprise
Premium
Context: An Enterprise license is required to connect to a remote dataset in Premium Capacity.
Answer: Enterprise

Question: With a _______ Tabular Editor 3 license, you can connect to a remote dataset in a Power BI Premium Per User Workspace.
PossibleAnswers: Business
Desktop
MIT
Premium
Context: An Enterprise license is required to connect to a remote dataset in Premium Capacity.
Answer: Enterprise

Question: Tabular Editor 3 cannot open _____ file types.
PossibleAnswers: .dax
.csx
.pbix
.pbit
Context: While Tabular Editor can open .pbit files (as they contain metadata information), it is not supported. Tabular Editor cannot open .pbix files.
Answer: .pbix

Question: What operating system does Tabular Editor run on?
PossibleAnswers: Windows
Mac OSX
iOS
Android
Context: Tabular Editor is a Windows application.
Answer: Windows

Question: True or False: To use Tabular Editor for Tabular Modeling, you need an internet connection.
PossibleAnswers: True - You need it to edit Data Models in Power BI Service
False - Tabular Editor only connects to Power BI Desktop as an External Tool
False - Tabular Editor is an Offline Tool
True - Tabular Editor needs it to format DAX.
Context: Tabular Editor can edit remote data models, but doesn't need to. You can work entirely offline, connected to model metadata or a local Power BI Desktop model.
Answer: False - Tabular Editor is an Offline Tool

Question: Which of the following data modeling features are possible to configure in Tabular Editor but not Power BI Desktop?
PossibleAnswers: Object-Level Security
Translations
Perspectives
Calculation Groups
Context: Some features do not have a user interface in Power BI Desktop, but are supported modeling operations. All of these are examples of powerful data modeling features which cannot be configured from Power BI Desktop.
Answer: All of the Above

Question: To benefit most from 'Personalize Visuals' in Power BI, you need to configure ______ in Tabular Editor, because it cannot be configured from Power BI Desktop.
PossibleAnswers: Personalization
Dynamic Visuals
Perspectives
Field Parameters
Context: Adding fields to perspectives and then enabling 'Personalize Visuals' limits the fields exposed to end-users. Creating tailored perspectives for specific report pages can be very valuable.
Answer: Perspectives

Question: True or False: Tabular Editor is intended for only enterprise Tabular Model developers.
PossibleAnswers: True: Tabular Editor is too complex for Analysts.
True: Tabular Editor is meant for Enterprise model development.
False: Tabular Editor can also be helpful for Analysts and Support engineers to analyze models.
False: Tabular Editor can be used also to all dataset types.
Context: Tabular Editor can bring value to all personas creating datasets and Tabular Models. It helps you make better models, faster.
Answer: False: Tabular Editor can also be helpful for Analysts and Support engineers to analyze models.

Question: Can you add new Excel data sources stored in SharePoint with Tabular Editor?
PossibleAnswers: Yes, you can add them by creating data tables and new M Partitions, then specifying the M code for the data connection and transformation.
No, SharePoint is not a supported data source.
Yes, you can use the 'Import Data Tables' to add it.
No, you cannot add new data sources with Tabular Editor, only modify DAX code.
Context: You can add any data source supported by the service. Supported sources by Tabular Editor are merely easier as the user interface will generate the M code for you, or add the explict source to the model.
Answer: Yes, you can add them by creating data tables and new M Partitions, then specifying the M code for the data connection and transformation.

Question: Which of the below features are not in Tabular Editor
PossibleAnswers: Preview data tables to view transactional data
Batch rename children to rename many model objects at once
DAX Debugger to break up complex DAX evaluations and navigate through each step
DAX Queries to query the model and show how long the query took to evaluate.
Context: All of the above are features of Tabular Editor. You can not only use it to help you write better DAX, but also add or manage data sources and Power Query, create/change relationships, test / validate the model, and perform complex automations, among other things.
Answer: None of the Above

Question: In Tabular Editor, you can test RLS using ______
PossibleAnswers: Impersonation + DAX Queries
Impersonation + C# Scripts
Pivot Grids without Impersonation
The 'Preview Security' feature
Context: Impersonation lets you run a query and view it as a user who has Build permissions, access to the dataset, and has been assigned to a security role. This works with DAX Queries, Pivot Grids and Preview Data.
Answer: Impersonation + DAX Queries

Question: What is the easiest way to view the Power Query of an Incremental Refresh table from Tabular Editor?
PossibleAnswers: When selecting the Table, in the 'Properties' pane, under 'Source Expression'
When selecting the Table, in the 'Properties' pane, under 'Polling Expression'
When selecting the Table, in the 'Expression Editor' pane, in the top-left, click on the Drop-Down that says 'Default Detail-Rows Expression' and select 'Source Expression'
When selecting the M Expression, look at the 'Expression Editor' pane to see the M code.
Context: The 'Source Expression' is the main 'Power Query' for the Incremental Refresh table. It can be viewed from the 'Properties' pane, but it is better to view it in the 'Expression Editor'.
Answer: When selecting the M Expression, look at the 'Expression Editor' pane to see the M code.

Question: When you edit the Power Query of a table to add or remove columns, what is the easiest way to modify the schema of the model table to add these columns?
PossibleAnswers: Right-click the table and select 'Update Table Schema...'
Add the data columns to the table and update their 'Source Column' property
Delete and re-add the table
Duplicate an existing column and change the 'Lineage Tag' property
Context: The 'Update Table Schema' property will automatically update the schema, adding or removing any columns. This can be done manually, by deleting the columns or manually adding them and updating the 'Source Column' property. The 'Lineage Tag' must always be unique; Tabular Editor already ensures this is the case behind-the-scenes, so you don't have to modify it, yourself.
Answer: Right-click the table and select 'Update Table Schema...'

Question: The easiest way to format ALL DAX in a model is with ______
PossibleAnswers: DAX Scripting
C# Scripting
Batch rename children
Debug Commas
Context: DAX Scripts let you edit multiple DAX objects at once. This lets you format all DAX in one, clean sweep, without writing custom C# code.
Answer: DAX Scripting

Question: You can edit a DAX expression and Format String at the same time in Tabular Editor using ______
PossibleAnswers: DAX Scripting
C# Scripting
Batch rename children
Calculation Groups
Context: DAX Scripts let you edit multiple properties of the DAX object at once.
Answer: DAX Scripting

Question: When making a new measure that references other measures, what is the fastest way to check their DAX expressions?
PossibleAnswers: Go to Definition
Peek Definition
Select the Measures from the TOM Explorer
Query the measures with a DAX Query
Context: If you right-click a measure reference and select 'Peek Definition', a mini-window opens beneath the reference showing the DAX definition.
Answer: Peek Definition

Question: True or False: When checking the definition of a measure with 'Peek Definition', you can change the DAX in the mini-window.
PossibleAnswers: True: This is an easy way to change the DAX of a measure reference.
True: But you can only change CALCULATE filter statements.
False: 'Peek Definition' cannot be used for checking measures, only Tables.
False: 'Peek Definition' only shows the DAX definition; to change it, you should use 'Go to Definition'.
Context: 'Peek Definition' lets you check the DAX definition in a mini-window, but you can't edit the DAX in this window.
Answer: False: 'Peek Definition' only shows the DAX definition; to change it, you should use 'Go to Definition'.

Question: You wrote some complex DAX code with a lot of variables. You decide that some of the variable names are too long, and you want to make them more concise; however, the variables are referenced in many places. What code-assist feature of Tabular Editor 3 will help, here?
PossibleAnswers: Refactor (Ctrl + R)
Select Multiple (Ctrl + D)
Select All Instances (Ctrl + Alt + D)
Find & Replace (Ctrl + F)
Context: Refactor (configured by default as CTRL + R) is the fastest way to change all instances of in-line definitions. Select All / Select Multiple can be configured from 'Tools > Preferences > Keyboard...'
Answer: Refactor (Ctrl + R)

Question: You are checking many objects in a big model, like measures, calculation items and calculated tables / columns. What navigation feature can make it easier for you to navigate back & forward across previously selected objects?
PossibleAnswers: Back (Alt + Left) and Forward (Alt + Right)
TOM Explorer Search
Find in Model (Ctrl + F)
Go to Definition
Context: Pressing 'Back' (Alt + Left) in the expression editor will automatically take you to the previously selected object. Once you've gone back, you can press 'Forward' (Alt + Right) to go foreward. When clicking through many objects, this can save a lot of time.
Answer: Back (Alt + Left) and Forward (Alt + Right)

Question: You are writing some complex DAX. Right now, you are writing the DAX in Tabular Editor, then saving your changes and testing it in Power BI Desktop. What feature in Tabular Editor can make this faster and easier?
PossibleAnswers: Use a DAX Query to test the measure, which you write with 'Define Measure' in the query scope.
A C# Script, to write and test the measure, automatically.
Script DAX, to write and test the measure, automatically.
You can use 'Format DAX' which will make the DAX easier to read and debug, later.
Context: Developing DAX from a query window and iterating the expression using 'Define Measure' is the preferred way of developing complex DAX code. This restricts development and testing to a single window, and you don't need to write changes to the model to test changes to the DAX; it happens within the query scope, only. Once you're ready, you can write the changes.
Answer: Use a DAX Query to test the measure, which you write with 'Define Measure' in the query scope.

Question: You are investigating a model that is experiencing performance issues. What tool in Tabular Editor should you use, first, to address the problem efficiently?
PossibleAnswers: 'Refresh Table' to test the table refresh speed.
'VertiPaq Analyzer' to see which columns in the model are taking up the most space.
'Diagram View' to see the tables and relationships.
'DAX Debugger' to debug the DAX of the measures one-by-one.
Context: Running the VertiPaq Analyzer will give you statistics about your model, illustrating tables/columns that are atypically large, and relationships with referential integrity issues.
Answer: 'VertiPaq Analyzer' to see which columns in the model are taking up the most space.

Question: Tabular Editor can save the model as a .bim metadata file or serialized folder structure (database.json). Why is a serialized folder structure helpful?
PossibleAnswers: It splits up each object into their own .json file sorted in folders, making it easier in Source Control to track changes on an object-by-object level.
It includes analysis from the 'VertiPaq Analyzer' which helps you analyze performance issues.
It ensures all objects are contained in a single 'database.json' and not separate metadata files, making deployment easier.
It is human-readable, so you can view it with any text editor or 'diff' changes in Source Control.
Context: The serialized folder structure (database.json) format splits up the model into separate .json files, which is beneficial for source control. It does not contain 'VertiPaq Analyzer' statistics (that is the .vpax format), and both database.json and .bim files are human-readable .json formats.
Answer: It splits up each object into their own .json file sorted in folders, making it easier in Source Control to track changes on an object-by-object level.

Question: You have used Tabular Editor to create two security roles 'RLS' and 'OLS', with permissions set on different objects. In the Power BI Service, you assign both roles to the same person. What is the result?
PossibleAnswers: The 'RLS' role will enforce Table Permissions while the 'OLS' role will enforce Object Permissions for the end-user.
The 'RLS' role will enforce Table Permissions, but the 'OLS' role will result in an error for the queried object, because RLS and OLS cannot be combined across roles.
The 'RLS' role will result in an error for the queried object, but the 'OLS' role will enforce Object Permissions for the end-user, because RLS and OLS cannot be combined across roles.
The end-user will receive an error when attempting to access the model or connected reports, because RLS and OLS cannot be combined across roles.
Context: RLS and OLS cannot be combined across roles, only within roles. When using both RLS and OLS, careful consideration must be taken to ensure a functional model design with the data security strategy.
Answer: The end-user will receive an error when attempting to access the model or connected reports, because RLS and OLS cannot be combined across roles.

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor, and receive the requirement to remove Row-Level Security, as it isn't necessary for this particular model. New users must not need to be added to security roles. What do you do?
PossibleAnswers: Refuse the request. RLS is necessary for all data models deployed to Power BI Premium or Premium-Per User workspaces.
Delete the Table Permissions, so that no filter expressions are applied on the model tables.
In the 'Properties' pane, set the 'Object-Level Security' to 'Read' for all Tables and Columns, across all Roles.
Delete all the 'Role' objects and their respective Table Permissions.
Context: So long as at least one Role exists in the model, users must have a Role assigned to be able to view model data, even if there are no Table Permissions. Data Security is often necessary and helpful in data models, but not obligatory.
Answer: Delete all the 'Role' objects and their respective Table Permissions.

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor. The 'Finance' users must have 'Build' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. The 'Sales' users must have 'Read' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. 'Sales' users must not see any data about Profit or Margin. Which of the below actions would be incorrect for you to fulfill this requirement properly?
PossibleAnswers: Configure two roles 'RLS' and 'OLS', with the appropriate permissions, giving the 'Sales' users both roles.
Put the 'Finance' users in their own App Audience which has 'Build' permissions to the underlying App Dataset.
Configure two roles 'Finance' and 'Sales', where both have RLS configured, but the 'Sales' role has additional OLS permissions applied.
Give both 'Finance' users and 'Sales' users read permissions to the dataset via their respective App Audiences.
Context: RLS and OLS cannot be combined across separate roles. They must be configured within the same role.
Answer: Configure two roles 'RLS' and 'OLS', with the appropriate permissions, giving the 'Sales' users both roles.

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor. The 'Finance' users must have 'Build' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. The 'Sales' users must have 'Read' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. 'Sales' users must not see any data about Profit or Margin. Which of the below actions would be incorrect for you to fulfill this requirement properly?
PossibleAnswers: Give the 'Finance' users the 'Contributor' role to the Workspace containing the dataset.
Give the 'Finance' users the 'Viewer' role to the Workspace containing the dataset, and 'Build' permissions to the specific dataset, itself.
Put the 'Finance' users in their own App Audience which has 'Build' permissions to the underlying App Dataset.
Put the 'Finance' users in their own App Audience which has both 'Build' and 'Reshare' permissions to the underlying App Dataset.
Context: Any user with 'Contributor', 'Member', or 'Admin' Workspace Roles will bypass configured data security (RLS or OLS); they will be able to see all data, because they have 'Write' permissions to the workspace datasets.
Answer: Give the 'Finance' users the 'Contributor' role to the Workspace containing the dataset.

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor. The 'Finance' users must have 'Build' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. The 'Sales' users must have 'Read' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. 'Sales' users must not see any data about Profit or Margin. Which of the below actions would be incorrect for you to fulfill this requirement properly?
PossibleAnswers: Give the 'Sales' users the 'Member' role to the Workspace containing the dataset.
Give the 'Sales' users the 'Viewer' role to the Workspace containing the dataset.
Put the 'Sales' users in their own App Audience which has 'Read' permissions to the underlying App Dataset.
Give the 'Sales' users 'Read' permissions to the specific dataset, without giving them additional permissions via App Audiences or Workspace Roles.
Context: Any user with 'Contributor', 'Member', or 'Admin' Workspace Roles will bypass configured data security (RLS or OLS); they will be able to see all data, because they have 'Write' permissions to the workspace datasets.
Answer: Give the 'Sales' users the 'Member' role to the Workspace containing the dataset.

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor. The 'Finance' users must have 'Build' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. The 'Sales' users must have 'Read' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. 'Sales' users must not see any data about Profit or Margin. Which of the below actions would be incorrect for you to fulfill this requirement properly?
PossibleAnswers: Write an RLS Table Permission filter expression 'Regions'[Email] = USERPRINCIPALNAME().
Write an RLS Table Permission filter expression 'Regions'[Email] = USERNAME().
Assign the security Roles to the respective user Azure AD Groups.
Assign App Audiences to the respective user Azure AD Groups.
Context: The USERNAME() function will return only the user's User Name, not their User Principal Name (E-mail), used in Dynamic RLS configuration.
Answer: Write an RLS Table Permission filter expression 'Regions'[Email] = USERNAME().

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor. The 'Finance' users must have 'Build' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. The 'Sales' users must have 'Read' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. 'Sales' users must not see any data about Profit or Margin. Which of the below actions would be incorrect for you to fulfill this requirement properly?
PossibleAnswers: Assign users to their respective Roles from within Tabular Editor.
Assign users to their respective Roles from the Power BI Service.
Configure all roles to have model permissions set to 'Read'.
Provision dataset permissions via the users' respective App Audiences.
Context: In Power BI, role assignment is done from within the Power BI Service, under dataset 'Security' settings.
Answer: Assign users to their respective Roles from within Tabular Editor.

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor. The 'Finance' users must have 'Build' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. The 'Sales' users must have 'Read' permissions to the dataset, but only see data for their own region. 'Sales' users must not see any data about Profit or Margin. Which of the below actions would be incorrect for you to fulfill this requirement properly?
PossibleAnswers: Validate the RLS filter expressions using a DAX Query.
Test the RLS and OLS in Power BI Service using 'Test as...' and creating ad-hoc, drag-and-drop visuals (DAX Queries).
Test the performance impact of RLS filter expressions from within DAX Studio.
Test the RLS and OLS in Tabular Editor using 'User Impersonation...' and creating ad-hoc, drag-and-drop pivot tables (Pivot Grid).
Context: In Power BI, it is not possible to test Data Security with ad-hoc queries. You can only test using the visuals in existing reports. In Tabular Editor, user impersonation enables testing with any DAX Query, Pivot Grid or Table Data Preview.
Answer: Test the RLS and OLS in Power BI Service using 'Test as...' and creating ad-hoc, drag-and-drop visuals (DAX Queries).

Question: You are managing a data model with Tabular Editor. You need to test that the configured RLS is working as expected with User Impersonation. Of the below conditions, what do you not need to configure to ensure you can perform this testing?
PossibleAnswers: Provision the user access to the dataset during testing.
Give the user 'Build' permissions on the dataset during testing.
Assign the user to their respective 'Role' via Power BI Service during testing.
Add the user to their respective 'App Audience'.
Context: In Power BI, testing with User Impersonation requires that the user being impersonated has (1) Dataset Access (Read Permissions), (2) been assigned to their respective Role, (3) Dataset Build Permissions. They should not yet be added to 'App Audiences'.
Answer: Add the user to their respective 'App Audience'.

Question: You have implemented Incremental Refresh in a Power BI Dataset deployed to Premium Capacity. How can you most efficiently validate the refresh policy from Tabular Editor?
PossibleAnswers: Run the 'VertiPaq Analyzer' and check the 'Partitions' window to see what partitions are there and how much data they hold.
In the 'TOM Explorer', check the 'Refresh Policy' partitions that were made in the 'Partitions' objects beneath the table.
In a DAX Query window, query the table.
Right-click the table and select 'Preview Data'.
Context: The 'VertiPaq Analyzer' will tell you (1) that the partitions were created and (2) that they contain data.
Answer: Run the 'VertiPaq Analyzer' and check the 'Partitions' window to see what partitions are there and how much data they hold.

Question: You can create custom ______ to display different windows for different use-cases, like Development vs. Optimization.
PossibleAnswers: Layouts
Windows
DAX Queries
C# Scripts
Context: Creating custom layouts is useful to have different displays depending on what you are doing. It is recommended to set up different layouts for different use-cases.
Answer: Layouts

Question: There is a problem with a custom M Function in your data model. You implemented the transformation in the upstream data source, instead. How can you find all of the M Partitions that referenced this function, and what step in the M code, so you can change the Power Query?
PossibleAnswers: 'View Dependencies' on the custom function
'Find' and search the name of the function in the entire model
Use a C# Script that uses Selected.Function while selecting the custom M Function
'View Dependencies' on the shared expression
Context: 'View Dependencies' only works with DAX. To find Power Query dependencies, use 'Find' to search the entire model. Searching the reference of the custom function will reveal which partitions reference it, and where exactly in the code the reference occurs.
Answer: 'Find' and search the name of the function in the entire model

Question: You are trying to debug a complex DAX expression with many variables, nested table expressions and CALCULATE functions. How can the DAX Debugger in Tabular Editor help?
PossibleAnswers: You can navigate through a 'Call Tree' of each step in the evaluation and see the variable values & filter context.
You can break down the DAX code into steps automatically and navigate through each one to find the problem.
You can manipulate the filter context, to see how the variables and evaluations change
You can navigate through the row context iterations to see how the variables and evaluations change.
Context: The 'DAX Debugger' is a powerful tool for investigating DAX code. It automatically breaks down the evaluation into pieces and lets you investigate them step-by-step.
Answer: All of the Above

Question: How can you start the 'DAX Debugger' in Tabular Editor?
PossibleAnswers: Right-click a cell on the pivot grid and select 'Debug this Value'.
Right-click a cell in a DAX Query using SUMMARIZE and select 'Debug DAX'.
Click the 'DAX Debugger' button and add your measure to the pop-up that appears.
Right-click a measure in the TOM Explorer and select 'Debug this Measure'
Context: You can start the debugger either by right-clicking the cell of a DAX SUMMARIZECOLUMNS query, or the Pivot Grid. It will then 'zoom in' on the DAX evaluation for that cell (using its filter context).
Answer: Right-click a cell on the pivot grid and select 'Debug this Value'.

Question: True or False: A user with 'Build Permissions' on a Power BI dataset can connect to that dataset from Tabular Editor if they have the right license.
PossibleAnswers: True: They will be able to connect via the XMLA Endpoint.
True: They can connect via XMLA Endpoint, but only in Read/Refresh or Read Only mode.
True: They can connect via XMLA Endpoint, but only in Read Only mode.
False: They cannot connect because Write Permissions are needed to connect with an XMLA Endpoint when XMLA Read/Write is enabled.
Context: Build permissions are not sufficient for connecting with Tabular Editor, even in 'Read Only' mode, at this point and time.
Answer: False: They cannot connect because Write Permissions are needed to connect with an XMLA Endpoint when XMLA Read/Write is enabled.

Question: You wrote a DAX measure and what to test what the evaluation will be with an empty filter context. What is the easiest way for you to do this?
PossibleAnswers: Using a DAX Query, write EVALUATE { [Measure] }.
Add the measure to a Pivot Grid with no other fields.
Right-click the measure and select 'Preview Data'.
Using a DAX Script, write EVALUATE { [Measure] }.
Context: You can evaluate measures in DAX Queries by specifying the appropriate DAX table expression syntax.
Answer: Using a DAX Query, write EVALUATE { [Measure] }.

Question: You added a new table in your model. You need to create a bunch of new relationships. What is the easiest way to do this?
PossibleAnswers: Add the tables to a new 'Diagram View' and drag-and-drop the fields to make the relationships.
Write a new C# script to make the relationships, automatically.
Right-click the table and select 'Make Relationships'.
Copy and paste the existing relationships onto the table.
Context: It's possible to do 'Clicky-Clicky-Draggy-Droppy' in Tabular Editor, just like Power BI. The diagram view is a really elegant way to
Answer: Add the tables to a new 'Diagram View' and drag-and-drop the fields to make the relationships.

Question: It is a best practice to organize your model fields into _______ so it is easier to use and find objects.
PossibleAnswers: Display Folders
Object Folders
Hierarchies
Measure KPIs
Context: Display Folders can hold Columns, Measures and Hierarchies. It's a best practice to use them in a structured manner to organize your model.
Answer: Display Folders

Question: You create a new relationship in the model, but are getting an error when running a DAX Query. Your relationship is configured properly, and the error goes away if you delete the relationship. What is most likely the problem?
PossibleAnswers: You need to perform a 'Calculate Refresh' on the model to process the relationship.
The relationship is Bi-Directional, which is not supported.
The relationship is a Weak Relationship, which is not supported.
You need to right-click the tables linked by the relationship and select 'Full Refresh', because the VertiPaq engine needs to create a new index for the columns.
Context: A relationship is an in-memory DAX object in the model. You need to process any new in-memory objects before they are used. This is most efficiently done by running a model 'Calculate Refresh'.
Answer: You need to perform a 'Calculate Refresh' on the model to process the relationship.
